ch1_s1.text:
11:47 PM. Rain hammers the city like a guilty conscience. You're outside the Blue Orchid when a woman's scream tears through the alley behind you. Your .38 feels heavier than the city tonight. A single streetlamp buzzes as if keeping time with your pulse.

You step toward the mouth of the alley and taste copper on the air. Some nights give you answers. Tonight smells like questions.

choices.label: Draw your gun and charge into the alley
Light a cigarette and listen first

ch1_s2.text:
Gun up, you push past stacked crates. Blood beads on cardboard like a slow confession. A woman in red clutches a locket, her breath coming shallow and quick. Footsteps retreat into shadow — too quick, too light.

You taste ash and the raw edge of urgency. This neighborhood owes you answers. Tonight it might pay. There is a name stitched into the locket. It's a name you don't like.

choices.label: Follow the footsteps, don't lose him
Hold the woman and call the ambulance

ch1_s3.text:
You run. Rain steals your footprints but not the echo of his coat. He slips between a pawnshop and a shuttered bakery, a ghost with a purpose. You catch a glint of metal at his hip — not a gun, something polished, deliberate.

The chase bends around alleys that know how to hide secrets. You round the corner and the world narrows to breath and the scrape of boots. This chase smells like a setup.

choices.label: Tackle him now
Circle and cut him off

ch1_s4.text:
You tackle. Rain and luck conspire; he spills a cigarette case and a photograph. The photograph is of a child, smiling in sunlight. The back has a scribbled address. He breaths curses and lies like cigarette smoke. His hands are empty but his eyes are calculating.

You can hear sirens far away — or is that hope? Choices cling to you like wet cloth.

choices.label: Search the case for clues
Read the photograph and memorize the address

ch1_s5.text:
The case hides three things: a coin, a matchbook from the Red Anchor, and a folded note. The coin is old; the matchbook smells like an ashtray and cheap whiskey. The note reads: "Don't look under the pier. — M." You fold the paper into your palm like a hot coal.

You let the man go because you need answers more than a victory. You light a cigarette and decide where to burn the night next.

choices.label: Head to the Red Anchor
Go check the address on the photo

ch2_s1.text:
The Red Anchor smells like spilled secrets and broken promises. Bartender eyes you like you owe him time. A woman behind the bar hums a song that sounds like a threat. A man named Doyle slides you a napkin with a name and a street scribbled on it.

Someone at a table laughs too loudly. Someone else watches you breathe. You feel the city leaning in to hear what you'll say next.

choices.label: Ask about the name on the napkin
Threaten Doyle for answers

ch2_s2.text:
The address on the photo brings you to a third-floor walkup smelling of old milk and older noise. A tired man answers, eyes rimmed in suspicion and regret. He recognizes the child in the photo and speaks of a woman who disappeared like weather.

He hands you a small package wrapped in wax paper and tells you to bury this night. You pocket the package but keep the man's face. The city gives you a breadcrumb and expects you to find the loaf.

choices.label: Open the package now
Take it to a safe place

ch2_s3.text:
You lean too hard on Doyle; the room tenses like a trapped animal. A door opens and a woman steps out — not the kind who forgives debt. She points at you with nothing but mercy-free eyes. Men in suits that smell of rain and money step forward.

You promised to be careful. You forgot to be quiet. Sometimes noise is louder than bullets.

choices.label: Back down and listen
Walk out and follow the suits

ch3_s1.text:
Safe place turns out to be a church basement with bad fluorescents and better ghosts. You open the wax paper: two bus tickets and a lock of hair tied with red thread. The hair smells like lavender and fear. A note tucked inside says: "If you find this, run toward the sea."

You keep the tickets; you keep the hair; you keep your mouth closed. Choices are sharp as a preacher's sermon here.

choices.label: Use the bus tickets to chase the lead
Follow the sea lead instead

ch3_s2.text:
You tail the suits to a warehouse by the docks where fog eats light. Men move crates like they move lies: quietly and on schedule. You slip inside, heartbeat a metronome beneath your ribs. Inside, crates are full of toys stamped with a children's charity logo.

There are names on the boxes. Names you recognize and wish you didn't. Some networks run deeper than a night's rain.

choices.label: Document the names and leave
Confront the man in charge

ch3_s3.text:
The sea tastes like salt and stories when you reach the pier. A boy fishes under a light that coughs and dies. He tells you a name — three syllables you couldn't forget even if you tried. He gives you a small tin with a child's doodle inside.

You feel the weight of that doodle like a promise. The pier creaks like a throat clearing: someone else is coming.

choices.label: Stay and wait for whoever's coming
Leave the pier and follow a different lead

ch3_s4.text:
You make a list of names in the dust on your dashboard. One name doesn't fit the rest; it fits in your mouth like a coin. You realize someone has been coaching witnesses, rewriting memories one lie at a time. This isn't a snatch-and-run; it's a slow, deliberate burn.

You decide to trace the burn to its source. The city hums; you step toward the place where the hum is loudest.

choices.label: Go to the social registry office
Visit the charity HQ covertly

ch4_s1.text:
Registry files smell like bureaucracy and neglect. You find a stamped note that links the charity to a shell company. The signature belongs to a councilman who smiles on TV and eats justice in private. You copy the document with shaking hands and a steady pen.

Someone watches you from a phone screen you don't see. When you leave, the sky has the thinness of a liar's promise.

choices.label: Take the documents to a reporter
Confront the councilman directly

ch4_s2.text:
The charity HQ has a reception that smiles too hard. Photos of volunteers line the walls like a family album for strangers. A volunteer recognizes the doodle from the tin and goes pale. She whispers of a warehouse party where rich men buy luck and pretend it's charity.

Her hands tremble; you offer a cigarette and a plan. Plans look better when they have someone else to hold them.

choices.label: Attend the warehouse party undercover
Get the volunteer into protective custody

ch4_s3.text:
You meet the councilman under chandeliers and pretense. He pours you whiskey like a verdict. He calls names like currencies, trading futures for favors. He offers you a choice: walk away and live, or dig and die slowly.

You realize the city eats those who choose to be honest. Your hand steadies on the glass. Your mouth remembers what justice sounds like.

choices.label: Take a bribe and walk away
Decline and keep digging

ch4_s4.text:
Warehouse night smells of perfume and opportunism. You slip in, dressed in a borrowed life. Under a tent of fairy lights, deals are made and children are photographed, smiles stolen for invoices. You find a ledger with numbers that speak the language of trafficking.

A woman in a silver dress makes eye contact with you — a call for help disguised as flirtation. You pocket a page and leave with a promise to burn the ledger later.

choices.label: Publish the ledger with a reporter immediately
Use the ledger to blackmail the men quietly

ch5_s1.text:
The reporter smells like old news and new hunger. He wants the ledger but not the trouble that comes with it. You trade him the names for a meeting place and a time. He promises to run the story if you bring him irrefutable proof.

You feel like handing him dynamite with a wick and a smile. You can trust him to print the truth or to bury it — newspapers have elbows too.

choices.label: Set up a sting with the reporter
Keep gathering proof alone

ch5_s2.text:
Blackmail is a blunt instrument with a short temper. You send a message to one of the men and wait. He replies with a time, a place, and a photograph of someone you love. Your chest tightens; the world narrows to a single counting of breaths.

You realize your threats can cut both ways. You have to decide how much you are willing to break to fix this.

choices.label: Go to the meeting and play your hand
Burn the ledger and disappear the evidence

ch6_s1.text:
You plan like a man who knows the cost of mistakes. A rooftop gives you a view of arrival paths and exit doors. You wait, watching men arrive with pockets full of explanation and palms full of sin. When the lights blink, you move — not loud, not proud, just a clean motion.

The meeting turns into a trap you had hoped to avoid. You're onstage now; improv is not your strength.

choices.label: Trigger the reporter's camera and expose them live
Cut the power and plunge the room into chaos

ch6_s2.text:
Flashes, shouts, men scrambling like insects under a boot. The reporter broadcasts names, faces, hands in plates of scandal. Some men sprint for lawyers, others for exits. A figure slips a child into a car and drives into the night like it owes them money.

The world divides into those who run and those who stand. You're left holding a half-truth, which is almost as dangerous as a lie.

choices.label: Chase the car that took the child
Secure the women and children left behind

ch6_s3.text:
The lights die and men fumble for commands. You slip through shadows and find a back room where paperwork sleeps like corpses. A door opens and you see rows of crates labeled with codes — names encrypted into numbers. Some of the crates have small hands painted on them for the paperwork's conscience.

You take pictures with a trembling camera and your hands learn to be steady. The dark hides many sins, but your flashlight does not lie.

choices.label: Follow the crates' trail to a shipping manifest
Burn the paperwork and hope truth survives

ch6_s4.text:
You follow the car into industrial outskirts where the city forgets to look. The child is alive but scared, wrapped in someone else's jacket. A driver tries to bargain with you; his voice is a slippery thing. You trade words for the child's safety and realize bargains change people.

You get the child back and see a face in the rearview that will haunt you. The city is quieter when a small life stops trembling.

choices.label: Take the child to a safe house
Demand the face in the rearview explain himself

ch7_s1.text:
The safe house cures immediate fear but not the long shadow. The volunteer who runs it has tired hands and a calendar full of miracles. You sit with the child while she sleeps and count small breaths like rosary beads. Outside, men who used to be untouchable breathe and plan.

Hope needs protection. So do witnesses. You consider staying long enough to watch over both.

choices.label: Stay and help run protection
Go after those still pulling strings

ch7_s2.text:
The man in the rearview is a planner: sharp suit, clean shoes, surgical calm. He speaks in metaphors and threats; he asks what you want. You tell him you want truth. He offers compromise and a file folder. Inside is a list: names, dates, and a photo of someone you thought dead.

You realize the game is older than you and the rules are written in people's bones. Bargains sting, but sometimes they buy the only kind of progress you can afford.

choices.label: Accept the compromise and use the file
Destroy the file and burn the ties

ch8_s1.text:
You leverage the file like a crowbar against the city's bones. Doors open, then slam. Men who smiled before now look like men who lost a card game. You trade secrets for protection and make enemies into reluctant allies.

A woman you once loved calls and asks if you are still the man she left for safety. You answer with actions instead of words. Actions write the next chapter better than good intentions ever could.

choices.label: Use your allies to take down the councilman
Expose the network publicly and trust the law

ch8_s2.text:
You orchestrate a takedown with people who have nothing left to lose. They move like well-trained storms: precise, cold, efficient. The councilman loses his smile under bright lights and legal questions. Some men go to jail; some men get new addresses and new mouths to feed them lies.

You win a battlefield but the war keeps its teeth. You count the cost and realize some debts will never be paid in cash.

choices.label: Press for indictments and testimony
Let the system chew on what you put in front of it

ch8_s3.text:
You hand the dossier to the authorities and hope their teeth are sharp. Investigators file the papers and move. Red tape smells like both safety and surrender. In weeks that follow, small victories appear: arrests, public apologies, quiet resignations.

But the network reforms where it is weakest, like a vine finding new light. You didn't remove the root. You trimmed the leaves. The city breathes differently but not cleanly.

choices.label: Keep pressure on the institutions
Walk away and restart somewhere the sun remembers

ch9_s1.text:
Trials are loud and boring and full of lawyers who practice patience like prayer. Witnesses tremble on stands, voices thin but true. A key witness recants in the middle of testimony and your heart does a small, ugly flip. You discover the cost of a public fight: collateral truth.

Sometimes justice comes with a stain you can't scrub out. You hold the line while everything else tries to sway you.

choices.label: Expose the recanting with evidence you hid
Let the witness go and protect future testimony

ch9_s2.text:
You produce the hidden evidence: emails, receipts, photos that show coercion. The courtroom gasps and the judge leans forward like a man listening for a confession. The recanting witness returns to the truth with a shaking voice. Men who once bought silence now face a stack of subpoenas and a lifetime of bad press.

The city applauds in headlines; the alleyways clap in whispers. You feel a small victory — and the ache of its cost.

choices.label: Push for maximum sentences
Seek restorative justice for victims

ch10_s1.text:
You choose to guard the witnesses, to be a fence between truth and retribution. It is a quiet life of coffee at odd hours and watching the same hallway twice. The children learn to sleep without nightmares; the mothers learn to laugh again. It is not a flashy victory. It is the kind of work old men who loved once respect.

You find nights where your breath is not an accusation but a benediction. Sometimes the world fixes itself in small, steady stitches.

choices.label: Keep protecting; make the shelter permanent
Use your position to root out the remaining network

ch10_s2.text:
The remaining nodes are clever and bored and underpaid. You move like an undertow — slow, inexorable, cold. You expose a banker, a lawyer, a small-time fixer who liked power the way some men like perfume. They fall not with a bang but with the soft, legal thud of paperwork.

You wonder if changing names changes the hunger. The city keeps turning, but a few of its teeth have been pulled.

choices.label: Publicize the final names and close the case
Let the cases move quietly through courts

ending_bad_trigger.text:
Your bullet hits center mass. He falls. It was a silver cigarette case. The woman dies before the ambulance arrives.

The papers brand you a killer cop. CASE CLOSED — TRIGGER HAPPY

ending_blood_love.text:
Your bullet finds his heart. Vivian runs into your arms, tears mixing with rain. You saved her.

She calls you every night for the rest of your life. CASE CLOSED — BLOOD & LOVE

ending_too_late.text:
Marcus laughs, shoots her anyway. Your bullet comes one second too late. Some cases you never close.

CASE CLOSED — TOO LATE

ending_corrupt.text:
You take the cash and the quiet life becomes a cage of velvet and lies. You sleep easier at first, but every dream has a price. People stop looking you in the eyes. You stop looking back.

In the end, you trade your name for comfort. CASE CLOSED — CORRUPT

ending_broken.text:
You burn the ledger and watch the evidence curl into ash. Men continue their work elsewhere where you cannot find them. You have a moment of safety and a lifetime of questions.

The child sleeps, but the city keeps bleeding. CASE CLOSED — BROKEN

ending_fall.text:
You burn the paperwork in a fit of righteous despair. Fire feels like control until it severs the one thread of proof you had. Without the papers the trials collapse like scaffolding in a storm.

You learn that some righteous acts are really just surrender. CASE CLOSED — FALL

ending_legacy.text:
You stay and build protection like bricks stacked against weather. Years pass; children grow into adults who remember the kindness that kept them safe. You become a footnote in someone else's life and a foundation in theirs.

It is small and it is huge and it heals edges you thought were permanent. CASE CLOSED — LEGACY

ending_sacrifice.text:
You destroy the file and walk away into a life of faded shadows. You traded the chance for revenge for the safety of those who deserved innocence.

Sometimes doing the moral thing costs the thing you love most. You live with that choice like a stone in your pocket. CASE CLOSED — SACRIFICE

ending_truth.text:
You push for transparency and watch institutions trip over their own sins. The law moves clumsy but it moves. People are held to account in the open light.

It is imperfect, loud, and human — but it changes the map. You are tired, but you sleep without a blade against your neck. CASE CLOSED — TRUTH

ending_escape.text:
You hand evidence to the authorities and leave town before the ink dries. A new sunrise finds you in another city where taxis don't know your name. You live quieter, smaller, but alive.

Some victories cost the right to stay. CASE CLOSED — ESCAPE

ending_redemption.text:
You press until the courthouse doors close on men who thought themselves untouchable. Sentences carry weight and the guilty pay in ways that matter. You stand in the light of a slow, hard justice and feel the old weight lift a fraction.

It's not clean or whole, but it is something like healing. CASE CLOSED — REDEMPTION

ending_caseclosed.text:
You publish the names, the ledgers, the receipts, and the whispers become a storm. There are apologies on paper and new laws drafted in shame. The people you saved learn to walk in daylight.

You close the file with hands that tremble and a face that remembers. CASE CLOSED — FINAL
